claim: A person under 18 is always tried as an adult

supporting.text: In most jurisdictions, minors under 18 are tried in juvenile courts unless specific conditions are met.

attacks.text: In most jurisdictions, minors under 18 are tried in juvenile courts unless specific conditions are met.
Some jurisdictions automatically try minors as adults for certain serious crimes, regardless of age.
Even in jurisdictions with automatic adult trials for serious crimes, these cases are exceptions rather than the rule.
The definition of 'specific conditions' can be broad, leading to many minors being tried as adults in practice.
Studies show that the majority of minors are still processed through juvenile courts, even with broad conditions.

supporting.text: Legal systems often consider age as a mitigating factor, making adult trials for minors rare and exceptional.

attacks.text: Legal systems often consider age as a mitigating factor, making adult trials for minors rare and exceptional.
Some jurisdictions have provisions to try minors as adults for severe crimes like murder or terrorism.
Even in severe cases, psychological evaluations often prevent automatic adult trials for minors.
Public opinion and political pressure sometimes override age considerations in high-profile cases.
Judicial discretion typically ensures that such overrides remain exceptions rather than norms.

supporting.text: International human rights standards, such as the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, discourage trying minors as adults.

attacks.text: International human rights standards, such as the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, discourage trying minors as adults.
Some jurisdictions have laws that automatically try certain serious crimes committed by minors in adult courts, regardless of international standards.
The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is not legally binding in all countries, and some nations explicitly reject its provisions regarding juvenile justice.
Even in countries that follow the Convention, exceptions exist for severe crimes like murder or terrorism, allowing minors to be tried as adults.

supporting.text: Many countries have laws explicitly prohibiting the trial of minors as adults for certain age groups.

attacks.text: Many countries have laws explicitly prohibiting the trial of minors as adults for certain age groups.
Some jurisdictions allow minors to be tried as adults for severe crimes, such as murder or terrorism.
Even in jurisdictions allowing adult trials for minors, such cases are rare and require judicial review.
International human rights treaties, like the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, oppose trying minors as adults.

supporting.text: Psychological and developmental research supports treating minors differently in the justice system due to their immaturity.

attacks.text: Psychological and developmental research supports treating minors differently in the justice system due to their immaturity.
Some minors commit crimes with adult-like intent and understanding, justifying adult trials.
Even in cases of adult-like intent, neurological studies show minors lack full impulse control and risk assessment.
Public safety concerns sometimes override developmental considerations for violent offenses.
Alternative sentencing models exist that protect society while accounting for developmental factors.
